title: Throat Cancer: What to Know
author: Kendall K. Morgan, Kathryn Whitbourne

sections.heading: What Is Throat Cancer?
content: Throat cancer is any cancerous tumor that grows in either your throat or voice box. Your throat (pharynx) is a muscular tube that starts behind your nose and ends in your neck. Your voice box (larynx) is right under your throat. It's made of cartilage and contains vocal cords that allow you to speak.
Your pharynx is situated behind your larynx (voice box). (Photo Credit: iStock/Getty Images)
About half of throat cancers happen in the throat itself, while the other half start in the voice box. Usually, cancer in your throat starts in the flat cells that make up your throat lining.

These diseases tend to grow quickly. That's why getting diagnosed and treated early on gives you the best chance to get rid of the cancer and keep a good quality of life. Learn as much as you can so you’ll know what to expect.

Your voice box (larynx) sits at the bottom of your throat and contains your vocal cords.
Laryngeal cancer can grow in three parts of the voice box:
bullets: Nasopharynx: This is the upper part of your throat behind your nose. Cancer in this part of your throat is rare in the U.S.
Oropharynx: This part is behind your mouth. Cancer is most likely to grow in the tonsils, the back of the tongue, or the soft palate (the soft area behind the roof of your mouth ).
Hypopharynx: That's the narrow area behind your voice box.
Glottis: This holds your vocal cords.
Supraglottis: This is the area above the glottis (including the epiglottis, which is like a flexible lid for your windpipe).
Subglottis: This is the area below your vocal cords and above your windpipe.

content: Throat cancer has five stages:
Stage 0. You'll have abnormal cells in your throat that might become cancerous. Stage 0 cancer is also called carcinoma in situ.
Stage I. Your cancer is in a very early stage. It is 2 centimeters or less in size and limited to your throat.

Stage II. Your tumor is 2-4 centimeters in size and hasn't spread to your lymph nodes . Lymph nodes are part of your body's immune system. They filter out foreign substances, such as infectious bacteria and cancer cells. Vocal cords still move normally.
Stage III. Your tumor is larger than 4 centimeters or it has spread to your nearby lymph nodes. Your vocal cords may not be moving or the cancer may be growing in other parts of your throat.

sections.heading: Stage IV.
content: Your tumor may be any size, but it has already spread to other places including:

Your throat cancer could be at any stage when it's first diagnosed. Many cases aren't caught until after throat cancer has spread to one or more nearby lymph nodes. Stage III and IV throat cancers are harder to treat and more likely to come back after treatment.
bullets: Your neck, trachea, thyroid, esophagus, jaw, mouth, or other places
Lymph nodes that are large or on the other side of your neck (more than one lymph node may be affected)
More distant parts of your body, such as your lungs

sections.heading: Throat Cancer Symptoms
content: One of the challenges in medicine is that so many illnesses share the same symptoms. A plain sore throat or a cough usually isn’t a big deal. More often than not, they go away on their own. But sometimes, they’re symptoms of something more serious, such as throat cancer . When you have throat cancer you may have:
bullets: Voice changes such as cracking, hoarseness, or trouble speaking clearly
Trouble swallowing, chewing, or breathing
A feeling like something’s caught in your throat
A sore throat , cough (possibly with blood ), or earache that won’t go away
A headache
Pain in your ears or neck
A neck lump or soreness that doesn’t go away
Unexplained weight loss
Jaw stiffness
Bleeding in your mouth or throat
Loose teeth
Bad breath
Ulcers in your mouth or throat that don't go away

sections.heading: What does throat cancer look like?
content: Usually, it doesn't look like much or will be hard to see. That's because the tumors are small and usually buried deep in your throat. Only 20%-30% of people with throat cancer are able to see anything.
If you can see something, you may notice:

In most cases, your doctor will need to use an endoscope to see throat cancers. This is a flexible tube with a camera that’s lowered into the throat through your nose or mouth. The cancer will look like a mass on one side of your neck.
Early throat cancer symptoms

Most people with early throat cancer don't have any symptoms. If you do, you may see a lump or mass on one side. Usually, it won't hurt, but sometimes you may have some pain in the back of your throat. You may also have trouble swallowing.
bullets: One side of your throat looks different than the other
Red or white patches in your throat
Swelling

sections.heading: Is cobblestone throat cancer?
content: Cobblestone throat means that you have visible bumps at the back of your throat. It's a throat inflammation (swelling) coming from an infection, irritant, or something you're allergic to. It's not connected to throat cancer. Cobblestone throat can be treated with antibiotics or over-the-counter antihistamines (such as Benadryl), depending on the cause of your inflammation.

sections.heading: Throat Cancer Causes
content: Nobody knows for sure why throat cancer happens. Like other cancers, it arises when cells in your throat pick up genetic changes that make them grow too much or spread to other places. Those rapidly growing cells can turn into a mass (tumor).

In general, throat cancer is quite rare. Laryngeal cancer makes up 0.6% of all new cancer cases each year in the U.S., while oral cavity and pharynx cancers make up 2.9% of all new cancer cases each year.

sections.heading: Throat Cancer Risk Factors
content: Although the causes of throat cancer are unknown, some things can increase your risk, including:
Some other factors you can't change also influence your risk.
bullets: Smoking or chewing tobacco
Drinking too much
Infections, especially the human papillomavirus (HPV) and Epstein-Barr virus
Not eating enough fruits and vegetables
Having gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
Exposure to toxins, including asbestos , nickel, or sulfuric acid
Sex. Men are five times more likely to get it than women.
Age. Most people get diagnosed after age 65.
Race. African American men get throat cancer more often than other groups do.

sections.heading: Throat Cancer and HPV
content: There are well over 100 kinds of HPV. About 40 of them can spread if you have sexual contact with another person’s genitals, mouth, or throat. You can get oral HPV from oral sex. The infection goes away for most people in one or two years. But it doesn't always leave your system and can cause throat cancer years later.

Experts don’t know if having HPV alone can lead to cancer, or if you have to have another risk factor for it to happen (like being a cigarette smoker). But it causes about 70% of oropharyngeal cancer (which affects the middle part of the throat) in the U.S., with cases continuing to grow. Men have more cases of throat cancer than women have of cervical cancer, which is also caused by HPV.

Getting the HPV vaccine can protect you from the types of HPV that can cause throat cancer. It may also prevent it. Some evidence shows that there’s possible herd immunity if enough women and people assigned female at birth get the vaccine. But it’s still recommended for all young people. In the U.S., 54.5% of teens aged 13-15 have received two or three doses.

But it causes about 70% of oropharyngeal cancer (which affects the middle part of the throat) in the U.S., with cases continuing to grow. Men have more cases of throat cancer than women have of cervical cancer, which is also caused by HPV.

Getting the HPV vaccine can protect you from the types of HPV that can cause throat cancer. It may also prevent it. Some evidence shows that there’s possible herd immunity if enough women and people assigned female at birth get the vaccine. But it’s still recommended for all young people. In the U.S., 54.5% of teens aged 13-15 have received two or three doses.

content: Your doctor will examine you and ask about your general health, smoking and drinking habits, and sexual history.

sections.heading: How to check for throat cancer at home
content: If you think you're at risk for throat cancer, it's a good idea to check for it at home. But keep in mind that throat cancers are usually hard to see and may be hidden in parts of your throat you can't see. Not seeing throat cancer doesn't mean you don't have it. To check for throat cancer:
If you notice anything unusual that doesn't go away in a couple of weeks or gets worse or bigger, see your doctor.
bullets: Feel for lumps in your neck.
Look at the back of your throat.
Watch for red or white patches.
Pay attention to any lumps, bumps, or ulcers.

sections.heading: Throat Cancer Treatment
content: Doctors will try to get rid of the tumor, keep the cancer from spreading, and protect your ability to swallow and speak as much as possible.
Your treatment will depend on:
bullets: The stage of your cancer
Where it is located
Your general health
Your preferences

associated_bullets: The stage of your cancer
Where it is located

content: You may have one or more treatments. Talk to your doctor about your options to decide which you think is best for you. Treatment options include radiation, surgery, chemotherapy, targeted therapies, and immunotherapy.
Radiation for throat cancer

Radiation uses high-energy rays to kill cancer cells. It’s given outside your body by a machine, or inside by radioactive seeds planted near the cancer. Sometimes, radiation is the only treatment needed if your throat cancer is caught early. It can also be used with chemotherapy or surgery to treat more advanced stages of the disease.
Surgery for throat cancer
Surgeries to remove throat cancer will depend on where the cancer is and how advanced it is.

Surgery for small cancers. If your cancer is just on your vocal cords or the surface of your throat and hasn't spread to any lymph nodes, the tumor can be removed via endoscopy. Your doctor will use an endoscope and special tools or a laser to remove the cancer as completely as possible.

sections.heading: Laryngectomy.
content: If your cancer is in your voice box, your doctor may remove part of it. They'll leave as much as they can to limit changes in your ability to speak and breathe normally. Sometimes, they may need to take out your whole voice box. If they need to do this, they'll attach your windpipe to a hole in your throat so you can breathe. This procedure is called a tracheotomy. You'll have options to help you speak without a voice box.
Pharyngectomy. This surgery involves removing part of your throat. You'll need your throat reconstructed so you can swallow normally.
Neck dissection. If the cancer has spread in your neck more deeply, your doctor may need to take out many lymph nodes to check them for cancer.

sections.heading: Chemotherapy for throat cancer
content: Chemotherapy drugs can kill cancer and stop it from spreading. The drugs may be used before surgery to shrink tumors, or after to keep the disease from coming back. Some chemo drugs can make radiation work better.

content_blocks.text: Chemotherapy drugs can kill cancer and stop it from spreading. The drugs may be used before surgery to shrink tumors, or after to keep the disease from coming back. Some chemo drugs can make radiation work better.

sections.heading: Targeted therapy
content: Targeted drugs can starve cancer cells by blocking substances they rely on to grow. For example, throat cancers often depend on a protein called epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR). A drug called cetuximab works by targeting EGFR. Targeted drugs may be used together with radiation, chemotherapy, or other treatments.
Immunotherapy for throat cancer

Some immunotherapy drugs are approved for head and neck cancers, including throat cancers. They work by taking the brakes off your immune system so that it can help get rid of the cancer. Known as " immune checkpoint inhibitors," these drugs are the only type currently approved for throat cancer. You're more likely to use them if the cancer can't be removed with surgery or if other treatments don't work.
Rehabilitation
You may need additional help after surgery or other treatments. Your doctor may suggest you see specialists to help:
bullets: Take care of a surgical opening
Learn new strategies for eating or swallowing
Manage stiffness or pain
Speech therapy

sections.heading: Palliative or supportive care
content: Palliative care is focused on relieving pain or improving quality of life. Your doctor can prescribe medication to help you manage pain when you have cancer at any stage.
Throat cancer recovery dysphagia

"Dysphagia" means difficulty swallowing foods or drinks. Some of the treatments for throat cancer can cause dysphagia. Surgery to the pharynx or larynx can make swallowing difficult. Radiation can cause dry mouth and weaken the muscles and nerves you use for swallowing. If you had chemotherapy at the same time as radiation, the side effects may be worse.

Signs of dysphagia include coughing or choking when you eat, difficulty swallowing, or pain when swallowing. You may need to learn different ways of chewing and swallowing to prevent choking. Or you may need to rely on thickened supplemental drinks for a while. Let your doctor know if you're having trouble swallowing so they can advise on what to do.

sections.heading: Throat Cancer Prevention
content: You can't prevent throat cancer. But you can take steps to lower your risk, including:
bullets: Not smoking
Quitting smoking if you smoke
Drinking alcohol in moderation or not at all
Eating a diet with lots of fruits and vegetables
Taking steps to protect yourself from an HPV infection

sections.heading: Living With Throat Cancer
content: Having throat cancer and undergoing treatment is hard. You may have lasting side effects. But there's a lot you can do to live a long and happy life.
Take care of yourself. Your treatment might take a lot out of you. So get enough rest, exercise when you can, and fill your plate with healthy foods, such as fruits and veggies.
Quit tobacco and limit alcohol. Smoking and drinking can make treatments less effective, and they raise your risk of getting another cancer.
Keep your appointments . Your doctor will follow you closely for the first few years. They’ll look for any signs indicating the return of cancer.
See other specialists. If you're struggling with eating, swallowing, speaking, or other everyday activities, ask your doctor for referrals to a speech pathologist or other specialist who can help.

Don't forget your mental health. It's easy to ignore your mental health when you're worried about your physical health. If you're depressed, anxious, or managing other difficult emotions, reach out for help from a mental health professional.
Join a support group. It often helps to talk to other people who've been in your shoes. Ask your doctor or look for a support group in your area or online.

Don't forget your mental health. It's easy to ignore your mental health when you're worried about your physical health. If you're depressed, anxious, or managing other difficult emotions, reach out for help from a mental health professional.
Join a support group. It often helps to talk to other people who've been in your shoes. Ask your doctor or look for a support group in your area or online.

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Throat cancer can be in your throat or voice box. It won't always be easy to tell if you have it, but you can lower your risk by taking steps such as not smoking and protecting yourself against an HPV infection. Your treatment may include surgery, radiation, chemotherapy, targeted therapy, or other medicines depending on how advanced your cancer is and where it is located.

sections.heading: Throat Cancer FAQs
content: Is throat cancer curable?
Throat cancer can be curable, especially if it's caught early enough for a doctor to remove it with surgery. Ask your doctor what your outlook is based on your cancer stage.

sections.heading: Do people usually survive throat cancer?
content: The five-year relative survival rate for cancer in the throat or larynx is about 61%-69% based on the most recent data. But recent treatment advances mean that your odds will be better. They also will depend on how advanced your cancer is.
What can be mistaken for throat cancer?
Symptoms of throat cancer can be similar to those of common conditions, such as colds, sinus infections, or allergies.

sections.heading: How can I check for throat cancer at home?
content: You can check your neck for swelling or look for red and white patches at the back of your throat. Keep in mind, however, that throat cancer doesn't always have symptoms and can be in places that are difficult or impossible to see without medical tools. If you're worried you have throat cancer, see a doctor.
What does early throat cancer feel like?

Most people don't have any symptoms of throat cancer early on. And when they do, it's mostly a swelling in the lymph nodes or a lump in the neck. Other less common signs are persistent laryngitis and pain on one side of the throat that never goes away. If you have any of these symptoms, see a doctor.
